exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes a double inversion to emphasize the rarity and subsequent consequence of an event?
options: Seldom had the orchestra performed so poorly, nor was the conductor able to hide his blatant disdain.
Seldom the orchestra had performed so poorly, nor the conductor was able to hide his blatant disdain.
Seldom had the orchestra performed so poorly, nor the conductor was able to hide his blatant disdain.
Seldom the orchestra performed so poorly, nor was the conductor able to hide his blatant disdain.
exercises.answer: Seldom had the orchestra performed so poorly, nor was the conductor able to hide his blatant disdain.
exercises.hint: Negative adverbials at the start of a clause require the auxiliary verb to precede the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom had the orchestra performed so poorly, nor was the conductor able to hide his blatant disdain for the woodwind section.

exercises.question: The litigation process was so convoluted that the defendant was effectively ___ of his right to a fair trial by the sheer volume of paperwork.
exercises.answer: deprived
exercises.hint: Look for the verb that collocations specifically with the preposition 'of' in a legal or rights-based context.
exercises.example_sentence: The litigation process was so convoluted that the defendant was effectively deprived of his right to a fair trial by the sheer volume of paperwork.

exercises.question: Rearrange the components to form a grammatically correct Cleft Sentence focusing on the reason for the delay.
exercises.answer: It was the total communication breakdown that stalled the negotiations
exercises.hint: Start with the 'It' pronoun to emphasize the specific cause.
exercises.example_sentence: It was the total communication breakdown that stalled the negotiations for nearly three months.

exercises.question: Match the sophisticated phrasal verbs with their precise semantic definitions.

pairs.right: To treat a serious problem as if it were not important
To obtain or create something with great effort
To hide a difficulty in order to make a situation seem better
To strengthen or support something that is failing

exercises.hint: One refers to physical support, while others refer to concealing flaws.
exercises.example_sentence: The minister tried to paper over the cracks in the coalition government.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following heteronym as a NOUN: 'The board was asked to 'attribute' the success to the team.'
exercises.answer: /ˈætrɪbjuːt/
exercises.hint: Nouns usually have the stress on the first syllable in these pairs.
exercises.example_sentence: Flexibility is a key attribute of any successful entrepreneur.

exercises.question: Identify the correct usage of the 'Subjunctive Mood' in a formal parliamentary context.
options: The committee chairman moved that the meeting be adjourned until the following Tuesday.
The committee chairman moved that the meeting is adjourned until the following Tuesday.
The committee chairman moved that the meeting was adjourned until the following Tuesday.
The committee chairman moved that the meeting will be adjourned until the following Tuesday.
exercises.answer: The committee chairman moved that the meeting be adjourned until the following Tuesday.
exercises.hint: Formal motions or requirements use the base form of the verb.
exercises.example_sentence: The committee chairman moved that the meeting be adjourned until the following Tuesday to allow for further deliberation.

exercises.question: Given the volatility of the market, the CEO was ___ to committing any further capital to the venture without a guarantee.
exercises.answer: averse
exercises.hint: This adjective describes a strong feeling of opposition and is followed by the preposition 'to'.
exercises.example_sentence: Given the volatility of the market, the CEO was averse to committing any further capital to the venture.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using negative inversion starting with 'Under no circumstances'.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances must the containment seal be broken
exercises.hint: The modal verb must immediately follow the introductory phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances must the containment seal be broken, as it would risk environmental catastrophe.

exercises.question: Match the grammatical terms to their advanced examples.

pairs.right: Had I known the truth, I would have acted.
Winning the championship required immense grit.
Having finished the report, he left the office.
What he needs is a long period of rest.

exercises.hint: Focus on the structure of the initial clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Had I known the truth, the outcome would have been vastly different.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'indefatigable', ensuring the primary stress is on the correct syllable.
exercises.answer: /ˌɪndɪˈfætɪɡəbl̩/
exercises.hint: The stress falls on the third syllable: in-de-FAT-i-ga-ble.
exercises.example_sentence: His indefatigable spirit allowed him to complete the marathon despite the injury.

exercises.question: Which sentence demonstrates the correct use of a perfect infinitive to express an unfulfilled past possibility?
options: He was to have joined us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely.
He was to join us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely.
He had to have joined us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely.
He would join us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely.
exercises.answer: He was to have joined us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely.
exercises.hint: The structure 'was/were to have + past participle' denotes a planned action that did not happen.
exercises.example_sentence: He was to have joined us for dinner, but his flight was delayed indefinitely due to the storm.

exercises.question: The candidate's performance in the debate was so lackluster that it ___ on the absurd, leaving the audience in stunned silence.
exercises.answer: bordered
exercises.hint: Choose the verb that typically takes the preposition 'on' to mean 'to be very close to a state'.
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate's performance in the debate was so lackluster that it bordered on the absurd.

exercises.question: Order the words to create an emphatic sentence beginning with 'Not only'.
exercises.answer: Not only did she win the race but she broke the record
exercises.hint: Ensure the auxiliary verb 'did' comes before the subject 'she'.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did she win the race but she broke the world record by five seconds.

exercises.question: Match these rare prepositions to their synonyms.
exercises.hint: Look for the most archaic or formal equivalents.
exercises.example_sentence: Notwithstanding the rain, the outdoor gala was a resounding success.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'anemone'.
exercises.answer: /əˈneməni/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: a-NEM-o-ne.
exercises.example_sentence: The clownfish hid safely within the stinging tentacles of the sea anemone.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes the 'future in the past' structure?
options: They were about to leave when the phone rang.
They had left when the phone rang.
They would have left when the phone rang.
They were leaving when the phone rang.
exercises.answer: They were about to leave when the phone rang.
exercises.hint: This structure describes an action that was imminent at a specific point in the past.
exercises.example_sentence: They were about to leave when the phone rang, forcing them to unpack their bags.

exercises.question: It is imperative that the researcher ___ the data with the utmost precision to avoid any skewing of the final results.
exercises.answer: analyze
exercises.hint: The word 'imperative' triggers the mandative subjunctive in American English and formal British English.
exercises.example_sentence: It is imperative that the researcher analyze the data with the utmost precision.

exercises.question: Arrange these words into a sentence using a fronted adverbial of place.
exercises.answer: On top of the hill stood an old man
exercises.hint: Place the prepositional phrase first, followed by the verb and then the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: On top of the hill stood an old man, gazing silently at the valley below.

exercises.question: Match the complex conjunctions to their functional usage.
exercises.hint: One of these specifically expresses fear or prevention of a negative outcome.
exercises.example_sentence: He whispered lest he should be overheard by the guards.

exercises.question: Pronounce 'precedence'. Note: do not confuse it with 'precedents'.
exercises.answer: /ˈpresɪdəns/
exercises.hint: Stress the first syllable. The ending sounds like 'ence' in 'science'.
exercises.example_sentence: Historical accuracy must take precedence over cinematic flair in this documentary.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences utilizes a 'nominalized' structure to convey the highest degree of formal objectivity?
options: The sudden resignation of the Prime Minister triggered a period of unprecedented market volatility.
The Prime Minister resigned suddenly and this caused the markets to become very volatile.
Because the Prime Minister resigned so suddenly, the markets started to fluctuate wildly.
The markets became volatile once the Prime Minister had resigned quite suddenly.
exercises.answer: The sudden resignation of the Prime Minister triggered a period of unprecedented market volatility.
exercises.hint: Nominalization replaces verbs with nouns to create a more detached, academic tone.
exercises.example_sentence: The sudden resignation of the Prime Minister triggered a period of unprecedented market volatility across the Eurozone.

exercises.question: Only after the committee had reviewed the forensic evidence ___ the lead investigator permitted to provide his testimony.
exercises.answer: was
exercises.hint: Inversion following 'Only after...' requires the auxiliary verb to agree with the subject 'the lead investigator'.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after the committee had reviewed the forensic evidence was the lead investigator permitted to provide his testimony.

exercises.question: Construct a grammatically complex sentence using a 'Fronted Comparative' structure.
exercises.answer: More important than the initial investment was the long-term sustainability plan
exercises.hint: The adjective phrase comes first, followed by the verb 'was'.
exercises.example_sentence: More important than the initial investment was the long-term sustainability plan proposed by the board.

exercises.question: Match the 'Modal + Perfect Infinitive' structures to their specific logical functions.
exercises.hint: Think about whether the action actually took place in the past.
exercises.example_sentence: You needn't have brought a gift, but it was very kind of you.

exercises.question: Pronounce the heteronym 'alternate' when used as a VERB (e.g., 'to take turns').
exercises.answer: /ˈɔːltəneɪt/
exercises.hint: The verbal form ends with a clear /eɪt/ sound, unlike the adjective.
exercises.example_sentence: The two speakers will alternate between English and French throughout the seminar.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly employs a 'Reduced Relative Clause' for concise formal writing?
options: The artifacts discovered during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age.
The artifacts which they were discovered during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age.
The artifacts discovering during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age.
The artifacts having discovered during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age.
exercises.answer: The artifacts discovered during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age.
exercises.hint: Passive relative clauses can be reduced by removing the relative pronoun and the verb 'to be'.
exercises.example_sentence: The artifacts discovered during the excavation date back to the Bronze Age and are in remarkably good condition.

exercises.question: Were it ___ for the timely intervention of the coastguard, the shipwrecked crew would almost certainly have perished.
exercises.answer: not
exercises.hint: This is a formal inverted second/third conditional structure.
exercises.example_sentence: Were it not for the timely intervention of the coastguard, the shipwrecked crew would have perished.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with an 'Adverbial Inversion' of place.
exercises.answer: At the foot of the mountain lay a small dilapidated village
exercises.hint: The verb 'lay' should immediately follow the location phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: At the foot of the mountain lay a small dilapidated village that time seemed to have forgotten.

exercises.question: Match the idiomatic grammatical collocations to their meanings.
exercises.hint: These are high-level adverbial and prepositional phrases used in formal discourse.
exercises.example_sentence: The efforts of the search party were, unfortunately, to no avail.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'mischievous', paying close attention to the number of syllables.
exercises.answer: /ˈmɪstʃɪvəs/
exercises.hint: A common error is adding an extra 'i' syllable; it should only have three syllables.
exercises.example_sentence: The mischievous child had hidden his sister's favorite toy in the garden.

exercises.question: Which of these sentences correctly uses 'Should' to express a tentative condition in a formal context?
options: Should you require any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department.
Should you will require any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department.
Should you would require any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department.
Should you have required any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department.
exercises.answer: Should you require any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department.
exercises.hint: This is an inverted form of 'If you should require...'.
exercises.example_sentence: Should you require any further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact our legal department during office hours.

exercises.question: The philosopher's arguments, ___ profound, were often criticized for being intentionally obscure and difficult to follow.
exercises.answer: albeit
exercises.hint: This conjunction is used to introduce a concession, similar to 'even though'.
exercises.example_sentence: The philosopher's arguments, albeit profound, were often criticized for being intentionally obscure.

exercises.question: Form a sentence using a 'Negative Inversion' with the word 'Little'.
exercises.answer: Little did the protagonist know that his life was about to change forever
exercises.hint: The auxiliary 'did' follows 'Little' to emphasize a lack of awareness.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did the protagonist know that his life was about to change forever that fateful morning.

exercises.question: Match the 'Future in the Past' structures to their contextual meanings.

pairs.right: An immediate intention in the past
A prediction made from a past perspective
A planned action that might have failed

exercises.hint: Consider the nuance between a planned event and an inevitable destiny.
exercises.example_sentence: That small startup was to become the largest tech giant in the world.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'epitome'.
exercises.answer: /ɪˈpɪtəmi/
exercises.hint: The final 'e' is not silent; it is a four-syllable word.
exercises.example_sentence: The architect's latest design is the epitome of modern sustainable living.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses an 'Adverbial Clause of Concession'?
options: Much as I admire his tenacity, I cannot support his unethical methods.
As much as I admire his tenacity, but I cannot support his unethical methods.
Admire his tenacity as I much, I cannot support his unethical methods.
Much as I admire his tenacity, yet I cannot support his unethical methods.
exercises.answer: Much as I admire his tenacity, I cannot support his unethical methods.
exercises.hint: 'Much as' is a C2-level equivalent to 'Although I like... very much'.
exercises.example_sentence: Much as I admire his tenacity, I cannot support his unethical methods in achieving results.

exercises.question: Such ___ the intensity of the storm that even the most seasoned sailors refused to leave the harbor.
exercises.answer: was
exercises.hint: This is an emphatic structure using 'Such' followed by the verb 'to be'.
exercises.example_sentence: Such was the intensity of the storm that even the most seasoned sailors refused to leave the harbor.

exercises.question: Order the words to create a sentence using a 'Participle Clause' of reason.
exercises.answer: Having spent his entire fortune the heir was forced to live in penury
exercises.hint: The perfect participle phrase explains the cause of the heir's situation.
exercises.example_sentence: Having spent his entire fortune, the heir was forced to live in penury for the remainder of his days.

exercises.question: Match the 'Dummy It' structures to their correct grammatical function.

pairs.right: Stating that an action is pointless

exercises.hint: These phrases allow a writer to avoid using 'I' while maintaining focus.
exercises.example_sentence: It remains to be seen whether the new policy will have any tangible effect.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'hyperbole', ensuring the final syllable is articulated correctly.
exercises.answer: /haɪˈpɜːrbəli/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: hy-PER-bo-le. The final 'e' is pronounced as a long 'e'.
exercises.example_sentence: The politician's speech was full of hyperbole and empty promises.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly employs a 'Double Passive' structure to discuss an objective perception of an past event?
options: The manuscript is believed to have been written by a scribe in the fourteenth century.
The manuscript is believed to be written by a scribe in the fourteenth century.
It is believed the manuscript to have been written by a scribe in the fourteenth century.
The manuscript was believed to be having been written by a scribe in the fourteenth century.
exercises.answer: The manuscript is believed to have been written by a scribe in the fourteenth century.
exercises.hint: Use the present passive of the reporting verb followed by a perfect passive infinitive for past actions.
exercises.example_sentence: The manuscript is believed to have been written by a scribe in the fourteenth century, though some scholars remain skeptical.

exercises.question: Rarely ___ such a blatant disregard for diplomatic protocol been witnessed on the international stage in recent decades.
exercises.answer: has
exercises.hint: The adverb 'Rarely' triggers inversion; the present perfect is required to link the past to the current 'recent decades'.
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely has such a blatant disregard for diplomatic protocol been witnessed on the international stage.

exercises.question: Construct a 'Mixed Conditional' sentence where a past action affects a present state.
exercises.answer: If he had taken the offer he would be a wealthy man now
exercises.hint: Combine a Third Conditional 'if' clause with a Second Conditional 'result' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: If he had taken the offer he would be a wealthy man now, but he chose integrity instead.

exercises.question: Match the 'Absolute Constructions' (noun + participle) to their functional equivalents.

pairs.right: If all goes according to plan
In spite of what has just been mentioned

exercises.hint: These function as independent adverbial phrases that do not modify a specific noun in the main clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Weather permitting, the launch will proceed as scheduled at 06:00 hours.

exercises.question: Pronounce the heteronym 'refuse' when used as a NOUN (e.g., waste or garbage).
exercises.answer: /ˈrefjuːs/
exercises.hint: The noun form stresses the first syllable and ends in a voiceless 's' sound.
exercises.example_sentence: The city council struggled to manage the sheer volume of household refuse generated during the holidays.

exercises.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses a 'Prepositional Gerund Phrase' to express a method.
options: By implementing stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency.
With implementing stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency.
In implementing stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency.
Through implementation of stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency.
exercises.answer: By implementing stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency.
exercises.hint: 'By + -ing' is the standard way to express 'the means by which' an action is achieved.
exercises.example_sentence: By implementing stringent capital controls, the central bank managed to stabilize the currency amidst the crisis.

exercises.question: Hardly had the ink dried on the peace treaty ___ skirmishes broke out again along the disputed border.
exercises.answer: when
exercises.hint: 'Hardly' and 'Scarcely' are paired with 'when', whereas 'No sooner' is paired with 'than'.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had the ink dried on the peace treaty when skirmishes broke out again.

exercises.question: Rearrange the words to form a formal sentence using 'Were' inversion for a hypothetical condition.
exercises.answer: Were the negotiations to fail the economic fallout would be catastrophic
exercises.hint: Use 'Were + Subject + to-infinitive' for a formal, hypothetical future condition.
exercises.example_sentence: Were the negotiations to fail, the economic fallout would be catastrophic for both nations.

exercises.question: Match the complex prepositional phrases to their more common synonyms.
exercises.hint: 'Dint' is an archaic word for 'force' or 'power'.
exercises.example_sentence: He succeeded by dint of sheer hard work and perseverance.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'choir', ensuring you avoid common phonetic misinterpretations.
exercises.answer: /ˈkwaɪə/
exercises.hint: It rhymes with 'fire' or 'wire', not 'chore'.
exercises.example_sentence: The cathedral choir sang a hauntingly beautiful rendition of the requiem.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses the 'Causative' structure to indicate a service performed by a third party?
options: The CEO had his legal team draft the nondisclosure agreement immediately.
The CEO had his legal team to draft the nondisclosure agreement immediately.
The CEO made his legal team to draft the nondisclosure agreement immediately.
The CEO got his legal team draft the nondisclosure agreement immediately.
exercises.answer: The CEO had his legal team draft the nondisclosure agreement immediately.
exercises.hint: 'Have + object + bare infinitive' is the active causative structure.
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO had his legal team draft the nondisclosure agreement before the merger was announced.

exercises.question: The suspect, ___ been spotted near the crime scene, was taken in for further questioning by the authorities.
exercises.answer: having
exercises.hint: Use the perfect participle 'having + past participle' to show an action completed before the main verb.
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect, having been spotted near the crime scene, was taken in for questioning.

exercises.question: Order the words to form a sentence with 'Subject-Verb Inversion' after a 'Neither' clause.
exercises.answer: He did not attend the gala nor did he send his regrets
exercises.hint: After 'nor', the auxiliary verb must precede the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: He did not attend the gala, nor did he send his regrets, which was considered quite rude.

exercises.question: Match the 'Bare Infinitive' triggers to their correct examples.

pairs.right: She helped him finish the work.

exercises.hint: These verbs and phrases do not require 'to' before the following verb.
exercises.example_sentence: You had better leave now if you want to catch the last train.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'hegemony'.
exercises.answer: /hɪˈɡeməni/
exercises.hint: The stress is typically on the second syllable: he-GEM-o-ny.
exercises.example_sentence: The empire's cultural hegemony lasted for centuries after its military decline.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates 'Conjunctive Inversion' with 'No sooner'?
options: No sooner had the curtain fallen than the audience erupted into a standing ovation.
No sooner the curtain had fallen than the audience erupted into a standing ovation.
No sooner had the curtain fallen when the audience erupted into a standing ovation.
No sooner the curtain fell than the audience erupted into a standing ovation.
exercises.answer: No sooner had the curtain fallen than the audience erupted into a standing ovation.
exercises.hint: 'No sooner' requires 'had + subject + past participle' followed by 'than'.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had the curtain fallen than the audience erupted into a standing ovation.

exercises.question: The ambassador's comments, however ___ intentioned, were perceived as a slight by the host nation.
exercises.answer: well
exercises.hint: Use the adverbial form to modify the participle 'intentioned'.
exercises.example_sentence: The ambassador's comments, however well intentioned, were perceived as a slight.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using a 'Negative Adverbial Phrase' to start the sentence.
exercises.answer: On no account should the confidential files be left unattended
exercises.hint: Place the modal verb 'should' immediately after the opening phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: On no account should the confidential files be left unattended in the lobby.

exercises.question: Match the types of 'Nominal Clauses' to their examples.

pairs.right: Whether he stays is his choice.

exercises.hint: These clauses function as the subject of the entire sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: That he lied about his credentials is now perfectly obvious to everyone.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'colonel', taking care with its non-phonetic spelling.
exercises.answer: /ˈkɜːnl/
exercises.hint: It is pronounced exactly like 'kernel'.
exercises.example_sentence: The colonel was commended for his bravery during the final assault.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes 'Ellipsis' to avoid redundancy in a complex formal comparison?
options: The first edition was successful, but the second even more so.
The first edition was successful, but the second was even more successful so.
The first edition was successful, but the second was successful even more.
The first edition was successful, but the second was even more successful than.
exercises.answer: The first edition was successful, but the second even more so.
exercises.hint: The phrase 'even more so' is a standard elliptical construction used to avoid repeating the adjective.
exercises.example_sentence: The first edition was successful, but the second even more so, thanks to a revitalized marketing campaign.

exercises.question: The company has developed a new prototype, the specifications ___ are currently being kept under strict wraps by the legal department.
exercises.answer: of which
exercises.hint: When referring back to an inanimate object ('prototype') in a formal possessive sense, 'of which' is preferred after the noun.
exercises.example_sentence: The company has developed a new prototype, the specifications of which are currently being kept under strict wraps.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a sentence using 'Fronted Adjective' inversion for dramatic effect.
exercises.answer: So silent was the house that the ticking clock sounded like thunder
exercises.hint: Start with 'So' + Adjective followed by the verb 'was'.
exercises.example_sentence: So silent was the house that the ticking clock sounded like thunder to his anxious ears.

exercises.question: Match the 'Non-gradable' adjectives with their appropriate intensifying adverbs.
exercises.hint: Non-gradable adverbs like 'absolutely' do not pair with gradable adjectives like 'good' or 'cold'.
exercises.example_sentence: The report was found to be entirely inaccurate upon closer inspection.

exercises.question: Pronounce the heteronym 'entrance' when used as a VERB (meaning to fill with delight or wonder).
exercises.answer: /ɪnˈtrɑːns/
exercises.hint: The verb form stresses the second syllable: en-TRANCE.
exercises.example_sentence: The sheer beauty of the landscape seemed to entrance every traveler who passed through the valley.

exercises.question: Which sentence demonstrates the correct use of 'Substitution' using the word 'one'?
options: The transition from a command economy to a market-based one is fraught with logistical challenges.
The transition from a command economy to a market-based economy one is fraught with logistical challenges.
The transition from a command economy to a market-based is fraught with logistical challenges.
The transition from a command economy to one market-based is fraught with logistical challenges.
exercises.answer: The transition from a command economy to a market-based one is fraught with logistical challenges.
exercises.hint: 'One' is used to replace the previously mentioned noun 'economy'.
exercises.example_sentence: The transition from a command economy to a market-based one is fraught with logistical challenges.

exercises.question: The software is designed to operate autonomously, ___ minimizing the need for constant human oversight.
exercises.answer: thereby
exercises.hint: This adverb is used to mean 'as a result of this' or 'by that means'.
exercises.example_sentence: The software is designed to operate autonomously, thereby minimizing the need for constant human oversight.

exercises.question: Order the words to form a formal sentence using 'Negative Inversion' with 'Only by'.
exercises.answer: Only by working together can we hope to overcome these obstacles
exercises.hint: The modal 'can' must come before the subject 'we'.
exercises.example_sentence: Only by working together can we hope to overcome these obstacles in the coming decade.

exercises.question: Match the 'Dependent Prepositions' to the verbs they must follow.
exercises.hint: Some of these are formal alternatives to 'agree' or 'finish'.
exercises.example_sentence: The celebrations culminate in a spectacular firework display over the bay.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'quay', noting its irregular phonetic correspondence.
exercises.answer: /kiː/
exercises.hint: It is pronounced exactly like the word 'key'.
exercises.example_sentence: The ship was moored at the quay while the cargo was unloaded.

exercises.question: Identify the sentence that correctly employs a 'Passive Gerund' following a preposition.
options: She expressed her extreme annoyance at being kept waiting for over an hour.
She expressed her extreme annoyance at being keep waiting for over an hour.
She expressed her extreme annoyance at been kept waiting for over an hour.
She expressed her extreme annoyance at keeping being waited for over an hour.
exercises.answer: She expressed her extreme annoyance at being kept waiting for over an hour.
exercises.hint: Use 'being + past participle' to form a passive gerund.
exercises.example_sentence: She expressed her extreme annoyance at being kept waiting for over an hour without an apology.

exercises.question: ___ the overwhelming evidence against him, the defendant maintained his innocence throughout the trial.
exercises.answer: Despite
exercises.hint: 'Despite' is a preposition and can be followed by a noun phrase; 'Although' requires a full clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Despite the overwhelming evidence against him, the defendant maintained his innocence.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to create an emphatic 'Cleft Sentence' with 'What'.
exercises.answer: What disappointed me most was his utter lack of professionalism
exercises.hint: Focus on the specific thing that caused the feeling using a 'What' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: What disappointed me most was his utter lack of professionalism during the negotiations.

exercises.question: Match the 'Vague Language' markers to their grammatical function in formal speech.

pairs.right: Referring to things of a similar kind

exercises.hint: These are used to soften a statement or generalize without listing every detail.
exercises.example_sentence: The shop sells vintage records, posters, and the like.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'ennui', paying attention to its French origin.
exercises.answer: /ɒnˈwiː/
exercises.hint: The 'e' sounds like 'on' and the 'ui' sounds like 'we'.
exercises.example_sentence: He was overcome by a sense of ennui during the long, monotonous rainy season.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'Whose' to refer to a non-human entity?
options: It was a decision whose repercussions are still being felt today.
It was a decision of which repercussions are still being felt today.
It was a decision that's repercussions are still being felt today.
It was a decision whose the repercussions are still being felt today.
exercises.answer: It was a decision whose repercussions are still being felt today.
exercises.hint: 'Whose' can be used as the possessive for both people and things in modern English.
exercises.example_sentence: It was a decision whose repercussions are still being felt today by the entire community.

exercises.question: Should you wish to cancel your subscription, you must do ___ in writing at least thirty days in advance.
exercises.answer: so
exercises.hint: 'Do so' is a formal substitute for a previously mentioned action ('cancel your subscription').
exercises.example_sentence: Should you wish to cancel your subscription, you must do so in writing.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using a 'Dangling Participle' (corrected into a formal Participle Clause).
exercises.answer: Fearing for his safety the witness was placed under police protection
exercises.hint: Ensure the subject 'the witness' is the person who is 'fearing'.
exercises.example_sentence: Fearing for his safety, the witness was placed under police protection immediately after the trial.

exercises.question: Match the 'Future in the Past' concepts to their syntactic examples.

pairs.right: They were to meet at noon.
I was going to help, but I forgot.
He was to become King one day.

exercises.hint: Each structure emphasizes a different aspect of how the future was viewed from the past.
exercises.example_sentence: He was to become the defining artist of his generation.

exercises.question: Pronounce 'ubiquitous' correctly.
exercises.answer: /juːˈbɪkwɪtəs/
exercises.hint: The stress is on the second syllable: u-BI-qui-tous.
exercises.example_sentence: Mobile technology has become ubiquitous in almost every aspect of daily life.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes the 'Mandative Subjunctive' to express a high-level formal requirement?
options: The bylaws require that every member be notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance.
The bylaws require that every member is notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance.
The bylaws require that every member should be notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance.
The bylaws require that every member being notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance.
exercises.answer: The bylaws require that every member be notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance.
exercises.hint: After verbs of requirement (require, mandate, insist), the base form 'be' is used regardless of the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: The bylaws require that every member be notified of the annual general meeting at least thirty days in advance to ensure transparency.

exercises.question: The candidate was ___ disappointed by the results, as she had expected a much higher margin of victory based on the exit polls.
exercises.answer: bitterly
exercises.hint: Which adverb forms a standard C2-level collocation with 'disappointed' to indicate a deep sense of personal regret?
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate was bitterly disappointed by the results, as she had expected a much higher margin of victory.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a sentence using 'Inversion' after a 'Only when' clause.
exercises.answer: Only when the dust had settled did the full extent of the damage become apparent
exercises.hint: The inversion 'did... become' must happen in the main clause, not the subordinate clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Only when the dust had settled did the full extent of the damage become apparent to the recovery teams.

exercises.question: Match the 'Gradable' adverbs to the adjectives they typically intensify.
exercises.hint: Collocations are essential here; 'subsidized' is almost always paired with 'heavily' in economic contexts.
exercises.example_sentence: The public transport system in the capital is heavily subsidized by the government.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'worcestershire', paying attention to its non-phonetic regional pronunciation.
exercises.answer: /ˈwʊstəʃə/
exercises.hint: The 'ce' and 'ter' are essentially swallowed; it sounds like 'Wusta-sher'.
exercises.example_sentence: He added a few drops of Worcestershire sauce to the stew to enhance the umami flavor.

exercises.question: Which of these sentences correctly uses 'Lest' to express a precaution against a negative outcome?
options: We must tread carefully, lest we provoke an unnecessary confrontation with our neighbors.
We must tread carefully, lest we should not provoke an unnecessary confrontation with our neighbors.
We must tread carefully, lest we provoked an unnecessary confrontation with our neighbors.
We must tread carefully, lest we will provoke an unnecessary confrontation with our neighbors.
exercises.answer: We must tread carefully, lest we provoke an unnecessary confrontation with our neighbors.
exercises.hint: 'Lest' is followed by the subjunctive (base form) or 'should' + base form; it inherently contains a negative meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: We must tread carefully, lest we provoke an unnecessary confrontation during the negotiations.

exercises.question: The negotiations were conducted ___ the backdrop of a looming global recession and heightening geopolitical tensions.
exercises.answer: against
exercises.hint: The standard preposition for 'backdrop' in a metaphorical context is 'against'.
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations were conducted against the backdrop of a looming global recession.

exercises.question: Form a sentence using the 'Passive' with an 'It is thought' structure and a 'Perfect Infinitive'.
exercises.answer: It is thought to have been the most significant discovery of the decade
exercises.hint: Use 'to have been' to indicate that the discovery happened in the past.
exercises.example_sentence: It is thought to have been the most significant discovery of the decade by the scientific community.

exercises.question: Match the 'Advanced Quantifiers' to their grammatical constraints.
exercises.hint: Consider whether the noun following the quantifier is countable or uncountable.
exercises.example_sentence: The museum displays a wide array of ancient artifacts from the Mediterranean.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'anachronism' correctly.
exercises.answer: /əˈnækrənɪzəm/
exercises.hint: Stress the second syllable: a-NA-chro-nism.
exercises.example_sentence: The appearance of a digital watch in a medieval drama is a glaring anachronism.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'Get' as a causative to imply persuasion or difficulty.
options: I eventually managed to get the technician to explain the system in layman's terms.
I eventually managed to get the technician explain the system in layman's terms.
I eventually managed to get the technician explained the system in layman's terms.
I eventually managed to get the technician to be explained the system in layman's terms.
exercises.answer: I eventually managed to get the technician to explain the system in layman's terms.
exercises.hint: Unlike 'have', the causative 'get' requires 'to' before the infinitive.
exercises.example_sentence: I eventually managed to get the technician to explain the system in layman's terms.

exercises.question: ___ that the CEO's strategy was flawed from the outset, the board decided to terminate the contract.
exercises.answer: Given
exercises.hint: This word is used to mean 'considering' or 'taking into account the fact that'.
exercises.example_sentence: Given that the CEO's strategy was flawed from the outset, the board had little choice.

exercises.question: Order the words to create an 'Inverted Unreal Conditional' sentence.
exercises.answer: Had we not intervened the situation would have degenerated into chaos
exercises.hint: Start with 'Had' to replace 'If we had not...'.
exercises.example_sentence: Had we not intervened, the situation would have degenerated into total chaos within hours.

exercises.question: Match the 'Double Conjunctions' to their logical functions.
exercises.hint: These are correlative conjunctions that must always appear in pairs.
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had the meeting begun when the fire alarm rang.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'vicissitudes', ensuring each syllable is distinct.
exercises.answer: /vɪˈsɪsɪtjuːdz/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: vi-CIS-si-tudes. Stress the second syllable.
exercises.example_sentence: The company has survived the vicissitudes of the market for over a century.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly reflects 'Reported Speech' for a past hypothetical statement?
options: He said that if he had known, he would have helped.
He said that if he knew, he would have helped.
He said that if he would have known, he would help.
He said that if he had have known, he would have helped.
exercises.answer: He said that if he had known, he would have helped.
exercises.hint: Third conditional structures do not change their tense in reported speech.
exercises.example_sentence: He said that if he had known about the deadline, he would have helped you finish.

exercises.question: The lecture was ___ fascinating that the students remained in their seats long after the bell had rung.
exercises.answer: so
exercises.hint: Use 'so' before an adjective to lead into a 'that' clause of result.
exercises.example_sentence: The lecture was so fascinating that the students remained in their seats.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a 'Gerund' as the subject and a complex complement.
exercises.answer: Maintaining a competitive edge requires constant innovation and strategic foresight
exercises.hint: The gerund 'Maintaining' acts as the noun subject of the verb 'requires'.
exercises.example_sentence: Maintaining a competitive edge requires constant innovation and strategic foresight in this industry.

exercises.question: Match the 'Attitudinal Adverbs' to their role in a sentence.

pairs.right: Expressing what is likely to be true
Conceding a point that may weaken one's argument

exercises.hint: These adverbs often modify the entire clause to show the speaker's perspective.
exercises.example_sentence: Admittedly, the plan has its flaws, but it is the best we have.

exercises.question: Pronounce 'quintessential' correctly.
exercises.answer: /ˌkwɪntɪˈsenʃl/
exercises.hint: The primary stress is on the fourth syllable: quin-te-SSEN-tial.
exercises.example_sentence: The village green is the quintessential image of the English countryside.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly employs a 'Pseudo-cleft' structure to highlight the specific action required?
options: What the management decided to do was to restructure the entire human resources department.
What the management decided to do it was restructure the entire human resources department.
That the management decided to do was restructuring the entire human resources department.
It was what the management decided to do restructure the entire human resources department.
exercises.answer: What the management decided to do was to restructure the entire human resources department.
exercises.hint: A pseudo-cleft uses a 'What' clause followed by 'be' to focus on the information at the end.
exercises.example_sentence: What the management decided to do was to restructure the entire human resources department to improve efficiency.

exercises.question: The evidence against the suspect was ___ circumstantial, yet the jury felt compelled to deliver a guilty verdict regardless.
exercises.answer: purely
exercises.hint: Which adverb collocations with 'circumstantial' to emphasize that there is no direct evidence?
exercises.example_sentence: The evidence against the suspect was purely circumstantial, yet the jury delivered a guilty verdict.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using 'Subject-Verb Inversion' following a prepositional phrase of direction.
exercises.answer: Towards the distant horizon slowly sailed the massive tanker
exercises.hint: In literary styles, the verb can precede the subject when the sentence starts with a directional phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: Towards the distant horizon slowly sailed the massive tanker, disappearing into the mist.

exercises.question: Match the 'Modal + Perfect Infinitive' to the speaker's degree of certainty.

pairs.right: Near certainty that it did NOT happen

exercises.hint: Consider the strength of the deduction being made about the past.
exercises.example_sentence: It must have been a mistake, as he is usually very meticulous.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'facsimile', ensuring you articulate all four syllables.
exercises.answer: /fækˈsɪmɪli/
exercises.hint: The final 'e' is not silent; it is pronounced as a short 'i'.
exercises.example_sentence: A facsimile of the original treaty was displayed in the museum.

exercises.question: Which of these formal structures correctly uses 'As' to denote a role or function?
options: He was respected as much for his integrity as for his intellect.
He was respected like much for his integrity as for his intellect.
He was respected as much for his integrity like for his intellect.
He was respected like much for his integrity like for his intellect.
exercises.answer: He was respected as much for his integrity as for his intellect.
exercises.hint: Use the 'as... as' correlative for equal comparisons of quality.
exercises.example_sentence: He was respected as much for his integrity as for his intellect throughout his career.

exercises.question: So ___ was the candidate's grasp of the subject that the interviewers were left with no further questions.
exercises.answer: thorough
exercises.hint: This adjective specifically describes a complete and detailed understanding.
exercises.example_sentence: So thorough was the candidate's grasp of the subject that the interviewers were impressed.

exercises.question: Reorder to form an emphatic sentence starting with the 'It' cleft.
exercises.answer: It was the CEO herself who authorized the unprecedented bonus payments
exercises.hint: Start with 'It was' to focus on the person responsible.
exercises.example_sentence: It was the CEO herself who authorized the unprecedented bonus payments last month.

exercises.question: Match the 'Discourse Markers' to their logical function in a debate.

pairs.right: Conceding a point but moving on

exercises.hint: These markers help signpost the direction of a complex argument.
exercises.example_sentence: The price is high; by the same token, the quality is exceptional.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'draught' (British English spelling of 'draft').
exercises.answer: /drɑːft/
exercises.hint: Despite the 'augh', it is pronounced exactly like 'draft'.
exercises.example_sentence: A cold draught came in through the gap under the door.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'Inverted Conditional' for a present/future hypothetical situation.
options: Should any problems arise, we have a contingency plan in place.
Should any problems would arise, we have a contingency plan in place.
Should any problems arisen, we have a contingency plan in place.
Should any problems were to arise, we have a contingency plan in place.
exercises.answer: Should any problems arise, we have a contingency plan in place.
exercises.hint: Use 'Should + Subject + Base Form' for formal first-type conditionals.
exercises.example_sentence: Should any problems arise, we have a comprehensive contingency plan in place.

exercises.question: The project was deemed a failure, ___ because of a lack of funding but due to poor management.
exercises.answer: not
exercises.hint: This is a 'not... but' structure used to contrast two reasons.
exercises.example_sentence: The project was deemed a failure, not because of a lack of funding but due to poor management.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using 'Fronting' for emphasis on the adjective.
exercises.answer: Exhausted though she was she continued to work until the task was finished
exercises.hint: Start with the adjective to emphasize the state of the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: Exhausted though she was, she continued to work until the task was finished.

exercises.question: Match the 'Reporting Verbs' with the grammar patterns they follow.
exercises.hint: C2 grammar requires precision in which verb takes which complement.
exercises.example_sentence: He denied taking the money from the safe.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'isthmus', paying attention to the 'th' which is often silent or softened.
exercises.answer: /ˈɪsməs/
exercises.hint: The 'th' is usually silent; it sounds like 'IS-mus'.
exercises.example_sentence: The Panama Canal was built across the isthmus connecting North and South America.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates 'Adjective Complement' using a to-infinitive?
options: The results are liable to be misinterpreted by those without statistical training.
The results are liable misinterpreting by those without statistical training.
The results are liable of being misinterpreted by those without statistical training.
The results are liable that they are misinterpreted by those without statistical training.
exercises.answer: The results are liable to be misinterpreted by those without statistical training.
exercises.hint: The adjective 'liable' is followed by a to-infinitive.
exercises.example_sentence: The results are liable to be misinterpreted by those without statistical training.

exercises.question: No ___ had the prime minister finished his speech than the opposition began their rebuttal.
exercises.answer: sooner
exercises.hint: Look at the word 'than' later in the sentence; it always pairs with this comparative adverb.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had the prime minister finished his speech than the opposition began their rebuttal.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a 'Nominal That-clause' acting as a subject.
exercises.answer: That the economy is recovering is evident from the latest employment figures
exercises.hint: The entire first clause starting with 'That' acts as the subject for the second 'is'.
exercises.example_sentence: That the economy is recovering is evident from the latest employment figures.

exercises.question: Match the 'Emphasis' techniques to their descriptive names.

pairs.right: I do hope you can come.
It was her who told me.
Never have I seen such a thing.

exercises.hint: Each of these shifts focus without changing the basic meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I do hope you can come to the party on Saturday.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'hierarchy' correctly.
exercises.answer: /ˈhaɪərɑːki/
exercises.hint: Three syllables: HI-er-ar-chy. The 'i' and 'e' are distinct.
exercises.example_sentence: There is a strict hierarchy within the military organization.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes 'it' as a preparatory object to handle a complex infinitive clause?
options: The legal framework makes it mandatory for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually.
The legal framework makes mandatory it for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually.
The legal framework makes mandatory for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually.
The legal framework makes it being mandatory for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually.
exercises.answer: The legal framework makes it mandatory for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually.
exercises.hint: When an adjective like 'mandatory' is followed by an infinitive, 'it' must act as a placeholder object.
exercises.example_sentence: The legal framework makes it mandatory for all corporations to disclose their carbon emissions annually to ensure environmental accountability.

exercises.question: The witness's account was ___ with inconsistencies, leading the prosecution to doubt the reliability of her entire testimony.
exercises.answer: shot
exercises.hint: In formal C2 English, which of these is often paired with 'through' or used alone to mean 'interspersed' or 'filled with' (negative contexts)?
exercises.example_sentence: The witness's account was shot through with inconsistencies, leading the prosecution to doubt her reliability.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a sentence using 'Negative Inversion' with 'Not until'.
exercises.answer: Not until years later did the true impact of the policy become clear
exercises.hint: The inversion 'did... become' occurs after the initial time phrase 'Not until years later'.
exercises.example_sentence: Not until years later did the true impact of the policy become clear to the general public.

exercises.question: Match the 'Complex Subordinating Conjunctions' to their formal definitions.

pairs.right: If a particular situation should arise
Because of a specific reason or evidence
Taking into account a particular fact

exercises.hint: These are used to connect clauses with high precision in academic and legal writing.
exercises.example_sentence: He was granted a pardon on the grounds that new evidence had come to light.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'indict', paying special attention to the silent 'c'.
exercises.answer: /ɪnˈdaɪt/
exercises.hint: It rhymes with 'excite' or 'polite'. The 'c' is not pronounced.
exercises.example_sentence: The grand jury chose to indict the official on three counts of corruption.

exercises.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses a 'Perfect Participle Clause' to indicate the sequence of events.
options: Having been informed of the delay, the passengers settled into the lounge for a long wait.
Informed of the delay, the passengers had settled into the lounge for a long wait.
Having informed of the delay, the passengers settled into the lounge for a long wait.
Being informed of the delay, the passengers having settled into the lounge for a long wait.
exercises.answer: Having been informed of the delay, the passengers settled into the lounge for a long wait.
exercises.hint: The passive perfect participle 'Having been + past participle' shows an action that happened before the main verb.
exercises.example_sentence: Having been informed of the delay, the passengers settled into the lounge for a long wait.

exercises.question: The architectural style of the building is ___ of the mid-century modern movement that swept through the city in the 1950s.
exercises.answer: reminiscent
exercises.hint: This adjective is followed by 'of' and means 'reminding you of something'.
exercises.example_sentence: The architectural style of the building is reminiscent of the mid-century modern movement.

exercises.question: Order the words to create a formal sentence with 'Adverbial Inversion' using 'Not only'.
exercises.answer: Not only was the theory provocative but it also lacked empirical support
exercises.hint: The auxiliary 'was' must precede the subject 'the theory'.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only was the theory provocative, but it also lacked empirical support from the scientific community.

exercises.question: Match the 'Focusing Adverbs' with their placement logic in a sentence.

pairs.right: Placed immediately before the element it restricts
Used to emphasize a surprising or extreme case
Used after a noun to mean 'without others'
Used to single out one particular thing

exercises.hint: Incorrect placement of these adverbs can fundamentally change the meaning of a C2-level sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO alone has the power to authorize such a massive expenditure.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'paradigm'.
exercises.answer: /ˈpærədaɪm/
exercises.hint: The 'g' is silent. It rhymes with 'time'.
exercises.example_sentence: This new research represents a significant shift in the scientific paradigm.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'Whom' following a preposition in a non-defining relative clause?
options: The mentor, to whom I owe my success, is retiring at the end of the year.
The mentor, to who I owe my success, is retiring at the end of the year.
The mentor, whom I owe my success to, is retiring at the end of the year.
The mentor, who I owe my success to, is retiring at the end of the year.
exercises.answer: The mentor, to whom I owe my success, is retiring at the end of the year.
exercises.hint: In formal English, the preposition precedes 'whom' when it is the object of that preposition.
exercises.example_sentence: The mentor, to whom I owe my success, is retiring at the end of the year.

exercises.question: The board's decision was ___ by the fact that the company had already incurred significant losses in the previous quarter.
exercises.answer: colored
exercises.hint: In a C2 context, this verb means 'to influence someone's opinion or decision, often negatively'.
exercises.example_sentence: The board's decision was colored by the fact that the company had already incurred losses.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using 'Subject-Verb Inversion' with an adverbial of 'Condition'.
exercises.answer: Should the negotiations reach an impasse the mediator will be called in
exercises.hint: Invert the subject and auxiliary to form a formal 'if' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Should the negotiations reach an impasse, the mediator will be called in to facilitate a resolution.

exercises.question: Match the 'Passive reporting structures' to their equivalents.

pairs.right: An unproven claim has been made
A strong argument is being put forward
A fact is admitted, often reluctantly

exercises.hint: These structures allow for a neutral, objective reporting style.
exercises.example_sentence: It is alleged that the executive embezzled funds from the pension pot.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'synecdoche'.
exercises.answer: /sɪˈnekdəki/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: si-NEC-do-kee. The 'ch' sounds like a 'k'.
exercises.example_sentence: Using 'wheels' to refer to a car is a classic example of synecdoche.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates the 'Inverted Second Conditional'?
options: Were he to resign today, the company's stock would likely plummet.
Were he resign today, the company's stock would likely plummet.
Was he to resign today, the company's stock would likely plummet.
Were he to have resigned today, the company's stock would likely plummet.
exercises.answer: Were he to resign today, the company's stock would likely plummet.
exercises.hint: Use 'Were + Subject + to-infinitive' for a highly formal hypothetical present/future.
exercises.example_sentence: Were he to resign today, the company's stock would likely plummet in the early hours of trading.

exercises.question: The novelist has a ___ for creating complex, flawed characters that resonate with a global audience.
exercises.answer: flair
exercises.hint: While 'knack' works, 'flair' implies a more sophisticated, artistic ability.
exercises.example_sentence: The novelist has a flair for creating complex, flawed characters that resonate with readers.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a 'Gerund Phrase' after a preposition.
exercises.answer: Despite being warned repeatedly he continued to ignore the safety protocols
exercises.hint: The preposition 'Despite' is followed by the passive gerund 'being warned'.
exercises.example_sentence: Despite being warned repeatedly, he continued to ignore the mandatory safety protocols.

exercises.question: Match the 'Nominal Relative Clauses' to their roles.

pairs.right: Referring to a destination or decision

exercises.hint: These clauses function as the noun subject or object of the sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: Whoever told you that the meeting was cancelled was sadly mistaken.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'ephemeral', ensuring correct stress.
exercises.answer: /ɪˈfemərəl/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: e-PHEM-er-al. Stress the second syllable.
exercises.example_sentence: The beauty of the cherry blossoms is notoriously ephemeral, lasting only a few days.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes a 'Counter-factual' structure following 'It is high time'?
options: It is high time the international community took decisive action against maritime piracy.
It is high time the international community takes decisive action against maritime piracy.
It is high time the international community should take decisive action against maritime piracy.
It is high time the international community had taken decisive action against maritime piracy.
exercises.answer: It is high time the international community took decisive action against maritime piracy.
exercises.hint: The phrase 'It is (high/about) time' is followed by a past simple tense to indicate a present or future action that is overdue.
exercises.example_sentence: It is high time the international community took decisive action against maritime piracy in the region.

exercises.question: The legislation provides a framework ___ the government can regulate the burgeoning artificial intelligence sector.
exercises.answer: whereby
exercises.hint: This relative adverb is used to mean 'by which' or 'through which method'.
exercises.example_sentence: The legislation provides a framework whereby the government can regulate the burgeoning artificial intelligence sector.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a sentence with 'Fronting' of a prepositional phrase for emphatic location.
exercises.answer: Beyond the shores of the island lay a vast and uncharted ocean
exercises.hint: Start with the spatial relationship 'Beyond...' followed by the verb 'lay'.
exercises.example_sentence: Beyond the shores of the island lay a vast and uncharted ocean, teeming with mystery.

exercises.question: Match the 'Complex Prepositions' to their semantic equivalents.

pairs.right: Following or as a result of
Conforming to a rule or request
Because of or through the power of

exercises.hint: These are essential for high-level formal and legal English.
exercises.example_sentence: He was granted citizenship by virtue of his marriage to a local resident.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'quay' correctly (Repeat for mastery).
exercises.answer: /kiː/
exercises.hint: Focus on the 'ee' sound; it is homophonous with 'key'.
exercises.example_sentence: The yachts were moored along the quay during the film festival.

exercises.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses 'Would' for a characteristic past habit with a sense of nostalgia.
options: Every summer, we would spend hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat.
Every summer, we would have spent hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat.
Every summer, we were would spend hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat.
Every summer, we would spending hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat.
exercises.answer: Every summer, we would spend hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat.
exercises.hint: 'Would' describes repeated past actions, often with an emotional or narrative tone.
exercises.example_sentence: Every summer, we would spend hours wandering through the ancient ruins, oblivious to the heat of the sun.

exercises.question: The CEO's tenure was ___ short by a series of scandals that eroded investor confidence.
exercises.answer: cut
exercises.hint: Use the phrasal collocation 'cut short' to mean interrupted or ended prematurely.
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO's tenure was cut short by a series of scandals that eroded confidence.

exercises.question: Order the words to create an 'Inverted Third Conditional' sentence starting with 'Had'.
exercises.answer: Had I not overlooked the fine print I would never have signed it
exercises.hint: This replaces 'If I had not overlooked...'.
exercises.example_sentence: Had I not overlooked the fine print, I would never have signed that contract.

exercises.question: Match the 'Future Continuous' and 'Future Perfect' to their logical contexts.

pairs.right: An action in progress at a future point
An action completed by a future point
The duration of an action up to a future point
A formal future arrangement or command

exercises.hint: Distinguish between the state of progress and the state of completion.
exercises.example_sentence: By next month, I will have been working here for twenty years.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'mischievous' (Repeat for mastery).
exercises.answer: /ˈmɪstʃɪvəs/
exercises.hint: Ensure there is NO 'i' sound after the 'v'. It has only three syllables.
exercises.example_sentence: The mischievous puppy had chewed through the internet cable.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates 'Adverbial Fronting' with a 'Negative Adverbial of Frequency'?
options: Hardly ever have I encountered such a profound lack of professional integrity.
Hardly ever I have encountered such a profound lack of professional integrity.
Hardly ever had I encounter such a profound lack of professional integrity.
Hardly ever have I encounter such a profound lack of professional integrity.
exercises.answer: Hardly ever have I encountered such a profound lack of professional integrity.
exercises.hint: Negative frequency adverbs like 'hardly ever' require 'auxiliary + subject' inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly ever have I encountered such a profound lack of professional integrity in this industry.

exercises.question: The candidate's argument, ___ well-reasoned, failed to address the underlying economic disparities.
exercises.answer: while
exercises.hint: In this context, this word functions as 'although' to introduce a concessive clause.
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate's argument, while well-reasoned, failed to address the disparities.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'Cleft Sentence' emphasizing the location.
exercises.answer: It was in the basement of the old library that the scrolls were found
exercises.hint: Use the 'It was... that' structure to pinpoint the place of discovery.
exercises.example_sentence: It was in the basement of the old library that the scrolls were found after fifty years.

exercises.question: Match the 'Gradable vs Non-gradable' adverb pairs to their appropriate adjectives.
exercises.hint: Remember that 'very' or 'extremely' cannot modify 'absolute' or 'limit' adjectives like 'finished' or 'dead'.
exercises.example_sentence: He was utterly exhausted after the sixteen-hour shift.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'repertoire'.
exercises.answer: /ˈrepərtwɑːr/
exercises.hint: The 'oi' sounds like 'wa'. It has three syllables.
exercises.example_sentence: The pianist has an extensive repertoire of classical and jazz pieces.

exercises.question: Which of these sentences correctly uses the 'Continuous Infinitive' to express an ongoing past action?
options: He was reported to be working on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.
He was reported to work on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.
He was reported to have worked on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.
He was reported to being working on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.
exercises.answer: He was reported to be working on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.
exercises.hint: 'To be + -ing' describes an action that was in progress during the reported time.
exercises.example_sentence: He was reported to be working on a secret project at the time of his disappearance.

exercises.question: ___ the circumstances, we believe that the current course of action is the only viable option.
exercises.answer: Given
exercises.hint: This past participle acts as a preposition meaning 'considering'.
exercises.example_sentence: Given the circumstances, we believe this is the only viable option.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a 'Relative Clause' with 'of which'.
exercises.answer: The antique table the legs of which were carved by hand is worth thousands
exercises.hint: Place the 'of which' phrase immediately after the noun it describes ('legs').
exercises.example_sentence: The antique table, the legs of which were carved by hand, is worth thousands.

exercises.question: Match the 'Elliptical' responses to their full grammatical meanings.

pairs.right: I hope that it is not the case.
If there are any at all.

exercises.hint: Ellipsis is common in C2 level discourse to ensure brevity and flow.
exercises.example_sentence: Are there any errors? If so, please correct them immediately.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'subtle', ensuring the 'b' remains silent.
exercises.answer: /ˈsʌtl/
exercises.hint: It rhymes with 'scuttle'. Do not pronounce the 'b'.
exercises.example_sentence: There were subtle changes in his behavior after the news was announced.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly utilizes the 'preparatory there' with a passive infinitive to discuss a potentiality?
options: There is reported to be a significant discovery made in the field of quantum computing.
There is reported to being a significant discovery made in the field of quantum computing.
There reported is a significant discovery to be made in the field of quantum computing.
There is reported a significant discovery to have been made in the field of quantum computing.
exercises.answer: There is reported to be a significant discovery made in the field of quantum computing.
exercises.hint: Use 'There + be + past participle + to be' for formal reporting of existence.
exercises.example_sentence: There is reported to be a significant discovery made in the field of quantum computing that could change encryption forever.

exercises.question: ___ for the timely intervention of the central bank, the entire financial sector would have faced an unprecedented collapse.
exercises.answer: But
exercises.hint: The phrase '___ for' is a formal C2-level equivalent to 'If it hadn't been for'.
exercises.example_sentence: But for the timely intervention of the central bank, the entire financial sector would have faced a collapse.

exercises.question: Arrange the words to form a sentence using 'Adjective Fronting' with 'as'.
exercises.answer: Strange as it may seem he actually decided to decline the prestigious award
exercises.hint: Start with the adjective 'Strange' followed by 'as' to create a concessive clause.
exercises.example_sentence: Strange as it may seem, he actually decided to decline the prestigious award for personal reasons.

exercises.question: Match the 'Reporting Verbs' to their corresponding complex grammatical patterns.
exercises.hint: Precision with verb complements is a hallmark of C2-level proficiency.
exercises.example_sentence: The director advocated implementing the new policy immediately.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'anemone' correctly, focusing on the sequence of nasal and vowel sounds.
exercises.answer: /əˈneməni/
exercises.hint: Four syllables: a-NEM-o-ne. The final 'e' is pronounced.
exercises.example_sentence: The sea anemone provides a protective habitat for various species of small fish.

exercises.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses 'no matter' as a conjunction for a complex concessive clause.
options: No matter how hard he tried to justify his actions, the board remained unconvinced.
No matter what hard he tried to justify his actions, the board remained unconvinced.
No matter how he tried hard to justify his actions, the board remained unconvinced.
No matter with how much hardness he tried to justify his actions, the board remained unconvinced.
exercises.answer: No matter how hard he tried to justify his actions, the board remained unconvinced.
exercises.hint: 'No matter' + 'how' must be followed immediately by the adjective or adverb it modifies.
exercises.example_sentence: No matter how hard he tried to justify his actions, the board remained entirely unconvinced.

exercises.question: The city council is ___ to implement a congestion charge, much to the chagrin of local motorists.
exercises.answer: set
exercises.hint: In a formal context, which of these indicates that a decision has been finalized and is ready to happen?
exercises.example_sentence: The city council is set to implement a congestion charge by the end of the fiscal year.

exercises.question: Construct a sentence using 'Negative Inversion' with 'On no account'.
exercises.answer: On no account should the confidentiality of the patients be compromised
exercises.hint: Place the auxiliary 'should' immediately after the negative phrase 'On no account'.
exercises.example_sentence: On no account should the confidentiality of the patients be compromised during this study.

exercises.question: Match the 'Absolute Adjectives' with the intensifiers that can legally modify them in C2 English.
exercises.hint: Absolute adjectives (non-gradable) require specific intensifiers that emphasize 'total' or 'near-total' states.
exercises.example_sentence: The craftsmanship of the Renaissance sculptor was simply exquisite.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'homage', taking care with the initial sound and stress.
exercises.answer: /ˈhɒmɪdʒ/
exercises.hint: The 'h' can be silent in US English, but in formal UK English, it is often pronounced. Stress the first syllable.
exercises.example_sentence: The director's new film is a clear homage to the French New Wave cinema.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates 'Inversion' after a 'Limit' adverbial phrase?
options: To such an extent did he dominate the debate that his opponent was left speechless.
To such an extent he dominated the debate that his opponent was left speechless.
To such an extent dominated he the debate that his opponent was left speechless.
To such an extent he did dominate the debate that his opponent was left speechless.
exercises.answer: To such an extent did he dominate the debate that his opponent was left speechless.
exercises.hint: The phrase 'To such an extent' triggers subject-auxiliary inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: To such an extent did he dominate the debate that his opponent was left utterly speechless.

exercises.question: The newly discovered manuscript is ___ to be the earliest known work by the Elizabethan playwright.
exercises.answer: reputed
exercises.hint: Which verb is used specifically for the positive general reputation or status of something historical?
exercises.example_sentence: The newly discovered manuscript is reputed to be the earliest known work by the playwright.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'Nominal Clause' as a direct object.
exercises.answer: The committee could not agree on what course of action should be taken
exercises.hint: The 'what' clause follows the preposition 'on'.
exercises.example_sentence: The committee could not agree on what course of action should be taken regarding the budget.

exercises.question: Match the 'Future in the Past' constructions to their typical use cases.

pairs.right: A result in a hypothetical past
An event that was destined to happen
An action that was on the verge of happening

exercises.hint: Focus on whether the past plan actually happened or not.
exercises.example_sentence: He was to have graduated in June, but he fell ill.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'colonel' (Repeat for reinforcement).
exercises.answer: /ˈkɜːnl/
exercises.hint: Ignore the 'l' and 'o' entirely; it is pronounced like 'kernel'.
exercises.example_sentence: The colonel was recognized for his strategic brilliance on the battlefield.

exercises.question: Which of these sentences correctly uses 'whose' to initiate a non-defining relative clause referring to an organization?
options: The charity, whose mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations.
The charity, that mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations.
The charity, of which mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations.
The charity, who mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations.
exercises.answer: The charity, whose mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations.
exercises.hint: 'Whose' is the standard possessive relative pronoun for both people and entities like charities.
exercises.example_sentence: The charity, whose mission is to provide clean water, has seen a surge in donations this year.

exercises.question: Should the proposal be accepted, it will necessitate a ___ overhaul of the existing administrative procedures.
exercises.answer: sweeping
exercises.hint: This adjective is a common C2-level collocation for 'changes' or 'overhauls' that affect many parts of a system.
exercises.example_sentence: Should the proposal be accepted, it will necessitate a sweeping overhaul of the procedures.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'Conditional Inversion' for a past event.
exercises.answer: Had the security protocols been followed the breach might have been averted
exercises.hint: Invert 'Had' and the subject 'the security protocols' to replace 'If... had'.
exercises.example_sentence: Had the security protocols been followed, the data breach might have been averted.

exercises.question: Match the 'Dummy It' structures to their semantic purpose.

pairs.right: Stating something that is obvious or logical

exercises.hint: These are high-frequency 'academic' placeholders used in formal debate.
exercises.example_sentence: It transpires that the witness had been lying the whole time.

exercises.question: Pronounce the word 'etiquette' correctly.
exercises.answer: /ˈetɪket/
exercises.hint: Stress the first syllable: ET-i-quette. The 'quette' sounds like 'ket'.
exercises.example_sentence: Diplomatic etiquette requires that all visiting dignitaries be treated with the utmost respect.

exercises.question: Which of the following sentences correctly utilizes 'Fronting' to create a smooth transition between sentences by emphasizing the adjective?
options: Crucial to the success of the project was the unwavering support of the local community.
The unwavering support of the local community was crucial to the success of the project.
